reviewText:
Fable. Yo. The Lost Chapters.
Alright where do I start?
This game was my CHILDHOOD.
I PULLED MY FIRST ALL NIGHTER BY MYSELF PLAYING FABLE THE LOST CHAPTERS ON THE ORIGINAL XBOX. If that isn't love, then I really don't know what is.
Let's get down to it.
Pros:
-Fun combat. Sort of basic hack n' slash action rpg fare. Now I love to be rewarded for me kills. Typo was unintenional but I'll leave it there.
So you got SWORDS, BOWS & ARROWS, AND CROSSBOWS, and MAGIC! For each type of way you eradicate your enimies, you get experience for that category of killing. So, if you bash a hobbe's brains out with a hammer, you'll get melee experience, then stick in between the eyes with an arrow, you'll get ranged experience, and then finish him off by burning him to a crisp with a fireball, you'll get magic experience. And to put icing on the cake, whenever you finish off an enemie, or an innocent civillian, whatever, you'll get general experience. HOW EXCITING.
Melee combat comes down to left clicking, blocking, dodging, and doing cool overpowered attacks with the right click when your weapon lights up. Ranged is holding down the left click to draw and charge your weapon then popping heads from afar. Magic is self explanatory even more so than the other categories. Do your thing, Harry. You are the chosen one.
-There are a lot of spells. Lightning, teleporting, reviving the undead, being a jedi and unleashing the wrath of hell.
-Obvious character evolution! Not only do you feel your character getting stronger but you can also see it. Upgrade your strength and become The Hulk. Upgrade your skills and become Shaq, because you get tall when you kill enemies with a crossbow or scam someone out of their money, because hormones work like that. Use magic and you'll turn into a super saiyan. No lie.
Another example of that character evolution would be your morality. I think morality systems in video games are dope. If you're nice, you'll get a pretty little halo will float above your head, butterflies will hoard you, and you'll grow angelicly. If you're evil and kill your sister lol, you'll grow horns and people will cower in fear.
-Chicken helmet. 'Nuff said.
-Story's a little cliched, but only really the beginning. You play some as some kid who's village gets burnt to the ground by bandits but a wizard saves and takes you to meet a short Hulk Hogan, who raises you to be a hero. The story then turns out to be a lot bigger than story of just vengeance will the balance of Albion hanging in your hands.
-The game doesn't take itself TOO seriously. There are serious moments but the overall tone and atmosphere of most of the zones is all laid back and chill.
-Soundtrack's pretty dope too.

Cons:
-The game's ugly. Oh
recommended: the game is ten years old
hoursPlayed:
well, I DON'T CARE. The game has not aged well. It didn't look good ten years ago. Deal with it. Anniversary edition looks beautimous though.
-Its pretty short. I don't have an exact estimate of how quickly I got EVERYTHING DONE in the game, but I got all the sidequests done, max'd skills, fully geared, ect and started a second playthrough in less than 30 hours.
-Your morality and story choices don't have a huge impact on the world. Yes, there are consequences for killing an important character at some point in the story, but it all really boils down to that the life you took was expendable anyway and their death would've decided whether people would talk smack to you or applaud you. Other than that though, the story is basically the same regardless of choices and the two endings are very slightly different.
-The game is really linear, zones are small and there a little opprotunities to go off the beaten path. However, if you can find a place to explore, you will most likely be rewarded.

In a nutshell, the game has a good but cliche story, fun combat, and you can get experience by eating meat. Buy it. Or the Anniversary edition for Xbox 360.

reviewText: I was stuck in Havana, Cuba for 2 weeks.  That city (and country) is a cesspool.  I was starving, sick, tired, and angry.  I was also cut off from electronic civilization.  No email.  No internet.  No phones.  No nothing.  It so happened that I had this game installed on my laptop and was able to play it in offline mode.  Accordingly, the hours I played this game were not clocked on my profile, but believe me...THIS GAME IS AMAZING.  It is older, but it maintains it's classic status.  For 2 weeks straight, the only pleasure I found in life was playing this game and roof drinking.  Do yourself a favor and buy this game.  Now.

reviewText:
Fable The Lost Chapters is an old Xbox port with some extra bits.The game has you playing through the story of a boy turned man who becomes either a hero or a villian.Like many of Peter Molyneux's games you have the constant choices during quest to do good deeds or evil ones.The world around you reflects which side you choose and your characters appearance changes .The story itself is interesting enough but its the storytelling presentation that won me over.

Weapons,skills & abilities in the game are your choice never being forced to pick any over another.They all have strengths and weaknesses but none outclass the others,other than in terms of damage.There are various outfits ,armors ,collectibles ,tropheys,and acclaim status to be gotten as you play.You can buy houses & rent them,barter for profit, get married,get divorced in the game as well.

The game world is linear but the world itself is decently sized and you will revisit area's often enough.The game sports teleporting from anywhere to specific nodes to help keep the ending running down well enough.The game is littered with humor and sidequests many of which the rewards are worth doing but completely skippable. For an old game its a good buy if you have never played it and want a decent linear action rpg.With a sweetfx mod the game looks even better. Get it 75% off on the cheap or get Fable Anniversary with all its new shiney looks.Either way worth that linear playthrough if you like rpgs.

reviewText:
Probably one of my favourite games of all time. I'm not a hardcore gamer though.
First things first, don't judge this game based from experience from Fable 2, Fable 3 or the journey.
The original Fable and the TLC edition are by far the best of the series and they started removing elements from the game such as the loss of a mana bar in Fable 2 and the health bar in Fable 3.

Why is this game awesome?
This game was one of the best of the Fable series thus far. It included the ability to slice your own destiny giving you the option to go full out evil with horns and flies buzzing around you or the choice of being good, being rewarded with a halo and popularity amongst the people of Albion. This game really emphasises the choice of your morality alignment, whether you wanted to have fun running around trying to take on guards or sacrificing people in order to receive a weapon; to just being able to stay clean and donating to the Temple.

What is it like?
This game is a sick Action Role-play game where the player gets to control a character and goes around bashing things with a sword swell as casting spells and spamming expressions to random villagers. While the environments aren't massive like the newer games they are sufficient and they are good enough for a basic casual gamer (like myself, they are pretty big to roam). The best thing about this game is being able to see character development. You start as a weak puny character that is a stick compared to the beast you become after you finish the storyline. It's a lot of fun mucking around with abilities.

Apart from the main story line which has some really intense kicks and shakes the player can also buy out properties and steal stuff all the actions you make do change your morality which is probably the biggest aspect as I mentioned before.

This game is worth more than it's price on steam and I really do highly commender it. Either TLC or the original edition, they are both beast :)

reviewText:
My thoughts on Fable - The lost Chapters:

I've played this game a lot when I was younger and didn't have Steam yet, that's why it says I've not played it at all and I'm still writing this recommendation. I got this game during a sale just because of the nostalgic feeling and so that I could tell you what an awesome game this is.

Fable was released on PC back in 2005 and got a lot of attention back then because of the freedom it gives the player and the impacts those decisions can and will have on both your character and the environment, which was a pretty much unknown feature.
You start the game as a young boy who's given several tasks, during which you're already forced to decide wther you want to finish them on the good or the bad way. Then, after some events, another tutorial and lots of talking, you're a grown up man who's (amongst other things) trying to figure out why those events happened and who's responsible for your parents death.
You'll be given several quests, you may explore the world and fight numerous enemies, gain exp and gain access to bigger and better spells (which can be upgraded too), weapons (which can also be upgraded, giving them some awesome visual effects) and armor. Houses can be bought, women married (and f*cked, though the screen becomes black), chicked can be kicked around, and whole cities can be murdered.

Cool thing about this game is, it always gives the player a choice. You can play it as a good guy, where you always help the innocent, never steal anything and never kill anyone who didn't deserve it. The more good things you do, the more saint-like your hero becomes, until you have your own halo and literally fart butterflies.
If you do things the evil way, your character grows horns, becomes pale and scares the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ out of everyone he encounters which makes getting a woman to marry you the most difficult task in the game (still a better love story than Twilight!). You can save a lot of money though by simply stealing the things that you need, and murdering an entire city is â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing funny!
The hero also adapts to the weapons you use - if you fight with spells most of the time, your arms start glowing, but if you use swords, you'll become a big beefy warrior. Eat much, and you'll become fat, but eat nothing and you'll be thin as a branch.

For a game that old the graphics and dialogues are still pretty good, the soundtrack is great and you'll be entertained for several hours. There may be lots of quests that are nothing special at all, but the freedom you enjoy in between is what makes this game one of the best I've played so far.
There aren't many bad things I can remember because it's been a while since I've last played it, but be sure not to be playing a perfect game. It has its flaws like any other game, but I can't remember anything that makes me want to say â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ this game".
There seems to be a HD remake of this game on the way (no idea when though)
recommended: only for the Xbox. Don't sue me if that's wrong.\n\nBuy it and enjoy!"

reviewText:
This is my favourite, and the best, RPG of all time. Period.

Yes, I have no game time right now - but don't judge the review on that just yet.

I remember back when I was younger, my brother had an Original Xbox, and Fable had just come out. He'd tell me how amazing it was and I always wanted to play it when he wasn't. After fighting to, I finally got to play and it was amazing. I'd spend all my free time on it when he wasn't using his xbox and it was just the best game I had ever played!
As an earlier birthday present one year, I got to choose between an Xbox or a Nintendo DS - Yes I chose the correct choice - I bought an Xbox Original for the sole reason of spending my days on Fable.

Fable is an amazing game, you make choices, buy and sell and collect items, weapons and armour. You have many expressions to make and learn, keys to find, chests to unlock and a lot of enemies to kill before killing the pfft...Almighty" End-Game boss.

Fable as a whole was an amazing experience. Not so long after

reviewText: Despite the tedious combat, this is a really good RPG game. It's somewhat short and quite linear, but there's enough interesting content in it to keep you busy for at least 20 hours. While a lot of the features are a tad superfluous. there is a good story, plenty of quests and a lot of interesting places to visit. The moral choices you have to make really add to the game. The only downside of the game is that the (melee) combat is just a lot of clicking. The training about blocking that you receive early in the game is rendered completely useless because you're (almost) always attacked by more than one enemy. Still it only lengthens the battles and doesn't really make them harder.\n\nRecommended for 10$ and a no-brainer for anybody who likes RPGs when it's on sale.

reviewText:
This is the first time I've played a Fable game and
I enjoyed this game mostly, I liked the story and that you could do bad, or good things or both. I like having a choice and not have to be a goody goody hero all the time.

Though I disliked and found it very frustrating that you could not save when doing a quest and should you fail, you have to start all the way from the beginning. That almost made me rage quit when trying to escort some spy and there was a massive amount of guards and no matter how much I tried he kept being killed as he dies in a few hits. So decided it was not worth the frustration to bother with that quest anymore.

The game is rather linear and the world seems quite small. Hirelings are rather useless with bad AI.
Despite the things I disliked I found the game fun and it kept me playing and wanting to see what is going to happen next.

I recommend this game if you like RPG's and a interesting story and don't mind that it's linear.
It's a bit too short for my liking. I completed the game in 30 hours and I did not rush and did all side quests but 1.
I'd give it 7/10.

English Version:
It was given to me about a year ago and I was pretty skeptic at first, but after playing it I had to change my mind; this game is amazing.

The plot is simple but nice. It tells the story of a young hero after his village, Oakvale, is raided by bandits. He's rescued by a hero, Daedalus, who leads him to the Guild of Heroes, where he meets Whisper, his roommate. After years of training, he becomes a hero and goes out on his adventure.

The gameplay is varied and is mainly based on two main aspects; ''Experience'' and ''Personality''.

reviewText:
This is not a proper review of the game, but in its place I will tell a story. This story will include a few spoilers, but let's be honest- the game is from 2004, the story will most likely have been spoiled for you at some point.

Let us begin. There once was a boy, brought into the great Guild of Heroes at a very young age, who trained hard night and day, dedicating his life to becoming a great Hero, seeking fame and glory. Even as a child the Hero was very boastful- proud of his physical and mental prowess and always seeking recognition for his accomplishments. But then one day the Hero took a boast that would later prove to humble him; the day had come that he enter the Arena, and the prideful Hero raised himself upon the podium outside the Guild's walls, looked down into the cheering crowd below.

This was, by this time, a familiar sight, for in his search for glory the Hero was not satisfied with merely completing a Quest. He would stand upon the platform and utter the most outrageous of boasts, at one time defeating an entire pack of Balverines stark naked without taking a single scratch as a personal test of his agility. His pride knew no bounds, and the Hero took upon himself the title of the divine Avatar, claiming that he would be the sword which the Gods wielded to drive back the darkness. However, this day the Hero saw an opportunity to forge a truly legendary tale within the Arena, one which could never possibly be surpassed: he would enter the Arena and slay all that came before him, be it man or beast, completely unprotected, and without a so much as a scratch to mar his rosy skin. The crowd cheering and his chest puffed with pride, the Hero set off to the Isle of Witchwood, and the Arena therein.

The Hero entered the Arena to the roaring of a crowd that could only brought on by the anticipation of imminent bloodshed. A veteran of the bloodied sands had just fallen, adding yet another entry in the long list of those who had died in pursuit of glory through combat. The Hero made short work of an entire nest of Wasps, then of a clan of Hobbes, all singlehandedly. From the third round on he would be joined by a fellow Hero to defeat the beasts that were released upon him. The gate lowered and from beyond came his greatest rival, a Heroine by the name of Whisper who had looked upon him with disdain ever since they had begun their training together many years ago. However, the Hero was satisfied with this, as it would only add to his legend, and so together they set about cutting down a pack of Balverines to pieces. By this time he had set into the familiar groove of combat, and with spell and sword his foes fell before him.

The Hero did not blink an eye as the remains of those who had died on the sands of the Arena tore themselves from the blood soaked earth and rose to reclaim their glory in death. After dispatching the Undead, a clan of Bandits, once feared throughout all of Albion and slated for execution within the Arena several years ago were next. Methodically he dodged their blows and cut them down one by one, Whisper his constant companion this a whirlwind of blood and blade. By this point it had become apparent that group tactics were no match for the Heroes' skill, and so the master of the Arena swiftly changed tactics and introduced a matched pair of trolls to the audience. The Heroes had already faced Trolls before, so as they saw the rumbling of the earth and the giant hands of stone emerge from the sod they knew what to expect. Cool and calm, they circled their prey, waiting for the opportune moment to strike and avoiding the attacks of the other troll. First a pair of Earth Trolls fell beneath their blades, then the even tougher Rock Trolls, chipped at repeatedly by their hit and run attacks.

With the defeat of the Trolls the Heroes stood tall, knowing they could take on anything. With the end near, the question of who the gold would go to should they win, as the Arena can only have one Champion,  arose, but this thought was quickly purged from minds as a massive creature the likes of which they had never seen before clawed its way out of the sands, stinger raised and claws snapping. The beast, a gigantic scorpion, was called Arachanox, and many a Champion candidate had fallen before her, their aspirations crushed along with their bodies under its massive stinger. This threat was novel, something the Heroes had never faced before, and it took a great amount of teamwork to learn its strengths and weaknesses. Carefully, they paced around it, dodging out of the way and poking at is when they could. The Hero had managed to maintain his boast of being untouched up until this point, as familiar foes had patterns which he could exploit. But in the face of the unknown his abilities remained sharp, but even the most skilled warrior eventually makes a mistake. Learning the patterns of the great beast the Hero hacked at it with his greatsword when it was stunned, retreating from the slashing of its pincers when it freed itself. They repeated this, but the long hours of combat had begun to wear on them, and the inevitable happened: the Hero made a mistake. Thinking the beast dead after an especially powerful blow, he raised his sword to the sky in celebration, to the delight of the crowd. But Arachanox was not yet defeated, and in its death throes it struck the Hero from behind, putting an end to his long line of successful boasts. Angered by the ruin of the legend he was trying to forge, he turned and struck it down, making sure it was dead, then turned to the cheering crowd.

Above them appeared none other than the legendary Jack of Blades to commend them for their valour. However, with his praise came a final, deadly, proposition: one final round. There could only be one Champion of the Arena, Unable to refuse this challenge or lose all they had just fought for, Whisper turned to the Hero and said that she could not kill him, not after all that they had been through in the Arena. The Hero then recalled his earlier boasting, declaring that he would cut down all he faced on the sands. He was a good man at heart, but he realized that his hubris had led him to this situation. Whisper's voice broke him from his thoughts, declaring that they should at the very least put on a good show. And so they crossed blades, once rivals, then allies, and now as reluctant foes on the field of battle. Whisper's skill proved to be no match for that of the Hero in the end, and as she kneeled in the sands, beaten, the Hero had a decision to make: would he sacrifice this woman who had caused him so much anger and betray the bond forged between them in battle to salvage at least some semblance of the legend he had hoped to create? As he looked down at her, he realized that he could not take the final blow and sheathed his blade, turning from the jeers of the disappointed crowd and the pleading eyes of Whisper to walk silently through the gates. With this he took an oath to never boast again, and became a true Champion of Righteousness, rather than a slave to the battlefield, going on to forge a legacy befitting the title of Avatar.

reviewText:
This game is fun. It really is.
When you play as an evil character, I found the constant screaming hilarious (for some reason it did not get old for me).
The same goes for the cheering when good.

Despite some of the things I list below the gameplay and story here are great.

Some things I hated about the game included:
-How stupid the AI is.
-I hate the idea of having multiple spouses (and the system for this is so dumb).
-Some bugs in the game that were annoying (particularly when a certain troll in front of a certain door doesnÂ´t appear).
-The hero save idea is horrible, especially early on.
-Why does the guild let people choose good or evil? What kind of guild is that...
-Some of the concepts in the game, namely what I just listed, are just incredibly illogical.

Simply put, there is a lot to the game I found illogical and mind blowing in that respect, but the gameplay is just too good for me to really have cared. Really it is a good game.

reviewText:
This game is The Hero's Journey: The Game.

The quests can get repetitive but the main story is good pulpy stuff. If you grew up watching Hercules, Xena, and/or Highlander, Excalibur, Dragonheart, you'll love it. The gameplay isn't anything extraordinary but it can be fun thwacking hordes of bandits with your BFS spamming Enflame and Multi-Strike. The stealth is unnecessary. Fishing can be tedious, and escort quests suck but all you need is to make them wait, clear out enemies, follow. Magic is fun.

What can you do? You can slaughter a village and buy up all the vacated buildings, or you can lead the inhabitants out to a different zone and buy their property if mass murder isn't your thing. You can collect silver keys, treasure clues, and goofy outfits. You can change your PC's hair, tattoos, and clothes. You can grow horns if you go full evil-and you get a halo for being fully good. You can sacrifice innocents for a sick bow, you can trade goods between shops for a limited profit, join Fight Club, show off trophies, shoplift, go fishing, figure out what the hell the demon doors want, and walk around in your Union Jack undies.

It's ludicrously easy to gain EXP once you fully understand how the combat multiplier works in conjunction to Physical Shield and how much EXP carrots, red meat, fish, and combat-oriented actions pay out. Hint: eat 150 red meats (3xp) with a x20 multiplier to equal 9000 Physique XP.

I wish they hadn't changed Jack of Blades' voice for The Lost Chapters, the original was more menacing. It was like changing Frieza's voice in DBZ Kai. Sure it makes more sense but it's not as cool.

Five stars.

reviewText:
A very entertaining single player, guided story RPG. There isn't a lot to say for the choices you make having much of an effect on the world around you. People like you different, your hair and eyes look different, and you're restricted from one or two spells; the only decisions that really matters are at the very end of the base game, and the expansion; which basically dictate one or two cinematics; in the expansion, you have three pairs of people you can kill one person each from, that's about it. The narrative however is quite good, and it appeals to the nature of a story that could quite go down as legend. You become a great hero in the span of years, and work to resolve your fate. The legendary items and gear make it feel more like an RPG, and the atmosphere is quite good. The only issue is, while great music, the lack of diversity in the music tracks makes some of the scenes rather... anticlimactic. When you're approaching the gates to armageddon basically, and the happy town music is playing.

End result, for $10, and those qualities ascribed?
Definitely a passing experience. Not excellent, but it's rather good.

reviewText: Hero, your health is low, do you have any potions or food?\n\nThe beginning of an excellent series, worth at least a decent playthrough for the common RPG players. Fable: The Lost Chapters is an expansion, continuing where Fable left off. The expansion includes new land masses, new items, and new characters, as well as re-introducing characters from the earlier stages of the game. Fable: The Lost Chapters includes the original game, so there is no need to purchase Fable as a standalone. Fable Anniversary was released in the recent past, and is a revamp of everything including The Lost Chapters. Overall rating for Fable: The Lost Chapters; 9.5/10

reviewText:
This is THE GAME.

On a personal note, I've never enjoyed any game as much as this one.

The story... is facinating and makes you want to pursue it all the way to the end without boring you even for a minute. Most quests also give you several choices during them which in turn make your status more evil or more good while twisting the means and/or the end result of quests.

Character customization... is well done. You can add tatoos, change your hairstyle, wear different clothes, have battle scars, get older... and all these together decide how NPCs see you and react upon your arrival. You can also get married which usually requires your character to be more attractive and renown.

Combat system... your combat skills don't advance along those lame skill trees" you often see in RPG games. In Fable you can choose everything yourself. If you want to max out all possible skills

In my opinion Fable TLC is the only Fable game worth playing. Fable TLC is a quirky humerous game that unlike its successors doesn't feel to streamlined. reviewText:
This game gives me nostalgie from when I first started gaming on my original Xbox. The story is good but not the best ever, what makes this game really shine is the cheery atmosphere and NPC interaction. It was also one of the first RPG's to include the good/evil scale which had influence on what you could do and what you looked like. The gaphics were also pretty good for their time.

There's tonnes of hilarious moments that you won't forget.

Overall experience 9/10

reviewText:
Game is incredible! This game is one of the funnest I have ever played. Got Fable 2 and Fable 3 on pc and neither of them are anywhere near how well done this one is. And to top it all off they are actually making a third version of the game! Fable Anneversarry! <-(Thats spelled wrong get over it!)
Other then that the gameplay is incredible. Graphics may not be as good as other games but if you are like me and play older games you will not even glance at that. Enemies are real tough to beat even if you are max level. Even after you beat the story line you still get to continue! Buying this comes with a DLC pack that continues the adventure even more!
Overall it is the best game/series of games I have ever seen. Fbles 2 and 3 are what I filled my summer years with when I got really bored. I have clocked over 50 hours on each of those games but this one will recieve more!
Buy it before it is to late!
20/10

reviewText: This is my favorite game and has been since I was 11 or so. This version is much much better than the Fable Anniversary, which I purchased for the bells and whistles... This one was by far a better choice, so I'd say save your money. Most people are saying don't buy II & III, I mean, they went really wide with both games and the ending of II frankly made me really angry. I am a die-hard fan of the series itself though and I don't want to play the same game over and over so I appreciate it. Lost Chapters is still the same old loveable Fable where you can decapitate traders and pelvic thrust at unsuspecting ladies, at a $20 difference in price.

reviewText: Fable was definitely one of my favorite games on the original XBox.  The PC version looks great and has the same excellent gameplay but it is completely bogged down by the horrible mouse/keyboard layout.  The flow of action is often slowed down by the constant which key am I supposed to be hitting" situation that often pops up.  It can be remedied a bit by downloading a decent gamepad program to map your keyboard but it is still a pain.  Sometimes you feel like you are going to have to hit a key with your nose or something since you are running out of fingers.  I still highly recommend this game however.  It is a classic."

reviewText: I remember playing the original Fable on the XBOX and loved it. Although I never could get all of the dolls.\n\nNow that the game is on the PC, it's still good. There's lots to do. You can rent out houses, you can slaughter (and own) most of the world, if you wish to be evil. Or you can be good and loved by the world. No matter which path you choose, I guarantee you'll love his game.

GREAT GAME! RECOMMEND TO BUY BEFORE YOU DIE!

reviewText:
Fable is one of those classically good games with very nice production value. It's primarily an action RPG where you play as an epic hero as you quest through the lands.

The game is full of humor and riddled with sidequests. But bare no bones about it, Fable is not a smart game by any stretch of the imagination. It's an action game first and an RPG second, and if you're determined enough you can beat the game without buying any equipment or levelling up your character in any way, I know this first hand.

So don't go into this expecting a game with the intelligence of Baldur's Gate, or any of Molyneux's other games, because it's not. Thankfully, the PC port is pretty solid and it features a completely extended part of the game after the original's ending.

Overall it's worth the 10$ on Steam and keeps your attention, but it's not anything to break an appointment over.

reviewText: Progression in the game is quite linear. In most instances, you will not be able to even leave the beaten patch, since fences, rocks, and invisible barriers won't allow it. Compared to more open-ended RPGs like the Elder Scrolls series, Fable seems restrictive and light weight in this regard. Overall, it's a decent story, but it is rather force-fed to you.

reviewText:
Take this with review a grain of salt because the only other video game I ever finished was Orcarina of Time back when I was a kid but I really loved this game. I missed out on the whole Fable thing back when it first came out but I'd always heard really good things about it so when I was looking for something to play on steam and saw it, I decided to give it a shot.

I really enjoyed it. It took me about 31hrs according to the statistics and I'm surprised it was only that long because I spent a lot of time just wandering around in the game, messing with charactersd, getting married, and things like that. It's really a good game with a lot of possibilities and definitely worth more than they're charging for it.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying this review's seriously biased: I had this game on the XBox OG and it blew my mind all over my poor mom's upholstery. Nostalgia may factor in here, but I'll try to maintain some sense of objectivity.


The good:

The gameplay of the original Fable was very unlike a lot of the RPGs in 2004. The mechanic utilized every decision you made to influence the story in some way or another. As enemies land hits on you, scars appear on your body. Do good deeds, the town loves you and a little halo appears on your head. Lay waste to all who stand in your way, and the potato-scrubbing plebians run in fear as little horns sprout out of your head. Your choices seriously affect your weapon stats, skill set, appearence, plot- every nuance of the game begins at day 1.

And remember, this is back in 2004. The DS was hot off the factory when this came out. Outkast's Hey Ya!" was not yet overplayed and annoying. Bush was still in office. That's impressive.

The music is also pretty impressive. Danny Elfman (yeah
date: THAT Danny Elfman) helped write the main score
hoursPlayed: the compser for a majority of Molyneux's games
voteText: actually used a small orchestra to do the majority of the game. Not the first or the last time a group of live people was responsible for a VG score
helpfulPercent: but again
votesHelpful: an impressive feat for an RPG of this scale considering we were still using Windows XP. It's atmospheric
votesTotal: and suits the naturally light-hearted nature of the game.\n\nThe game itself has bits and pieces of humor around. It's a game that tries to not take itself too seriously. The dry
votesFunny: snarky sort of humor only a crazy Brit could come up with. The animation and graphics
column16: are bright with just a touch of cartoony.\n\nStill
column17: the selling point here is that Fable set the standard for all the open-world RPGs that follow. Some of Fable's mechanics were borrowed
column18: sure
column19: and some it invented
column20: but I have to argue that it's really the first single player RPG that put it all together to make something that feels this open and massive in scale
column21: where your decisions and style of gameplay seriously affect the game. Really
column22: the closest relative I can think of is Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion in 2006
column23: a full two years after.\n\n(Maybe there's a hidden gem I missed
column24:
but I'm sure someone will point it out if I'm wrong about this.)


The ugly:

Oh
column26: the graphics have aged. It takes some getting used to. Even in 2004
column29: even with my GPU's antialiasing cranked up as far as she goes
column32: and cheap modeling.\n\nIt's not a dealbreaker by any means
column33: unless your idea of a good game rests solely on whether or not your dog's character model looks like a real dog. Like I said
column34: it does take a bit getting used to
column35: but the game is still so immersive
column36: you'll ignore it after a few minutes of real gameplay.\n\nThe contols are a bit awkward
column37: as well. Maybe it's just me
column38: or maybe it's from playing some more modern RPGs
column40: it feels like the red-headed stepchild: the controls are still reasonably well-laid (at least it's still using WASD)
column41: but there's just some modern conventions that are missing. You can remap the controls
column44:
but it's still a little clunky.


The bad:

The avatar-to-enviroment ratio isn't linear. At all. You can get some pretty powerful magic and weapons early on in the game. There's a couple of spells that are just straight up unfair- notibly the spell that slows down time
column45: and the "Heavenly Whatever/Infernal Thing" spells. Even late in the game
column47: all you need to do is slow down time for a bit
column48: and whack all the enemies in a 40-block radius with your Heavenly Thingamabob before they can land a single hit. Mix that with the fact that enemy strength barely goes up after 10 hours
column50: well-designed RPG turns into a hack-and-slash. The game does offer a chance to tack on challenges to your quests
column54: but it doesn't actually add challenge to a quest itself- it's just a bet. If you take damage during a no damage run
column55: you just lose a few gold
column56: and the quest continues as normal.\n\nBasically
column58: it becomes waaaaay too easy to just blast your way though a quest if you have the right upgrades. It's really a major oversight. It certainly doesn't ruin the game
column59:
but it is a nasty blemish that's hard to overlook.

Final verdict:

Go for it. It's ten bucks

column70:
and still has a few surprises left in her sleeve.

reviewText:
GAMEPLAY: 8/10
STORY: 8/10

A great start to a great series. The story is simple and interesting. In my opinion, Fable is NOT supposed to use a mouse and keyboard and the default key bindings are just strange. However, you can quickly adjust to this control style. I actually played Fable 2 first (which remains my favorite) and it was nice to see that good aspects got carried over in the series and the bad were left out or modified. Thus, after this game, I recommend getting Fable 2, and possibly 3 (not everybody likes Fable 3 and there are plenty of reviews to explain why or why not.)

Well worth the bucks.

You could become good or evil with a noticeable difference to your characters appearance to show this. The world is beautiful, happy and great fun to adventure through. The only downfall with this game is it's short time. If you have never played Fable before I can't reccomend this enough as I feel everyone should play through this game at least once.

reviewText: This is the game that takes the title as I favourite RPG ever. It may not have the size and content of Skyrim, but the impacts you make on the world really add to the immersion. People actually chanting your name and either cowering from you or praising you, and actually knowing when or when not to oppose you is something that even Skyrim fails to achieve. The combat may seem just like a button masher but if you know what your doing, you can turn it into a fun game of mind tricks with your opponents. The story is the cherry on top of this brilliant cake, and contrary to what many people say, the game can get pretty difficult.

reviewText: Fable: The Lost Chapters builds upon the original best-selling Fable with loads of new content including new regions, quests and enhanced story elements that further enhance the mystical world of Albion. Fable: The Lost Chapters gives players the chance to fight new monsters, use epic spells to obliterate huge numbers of enemies, don new armor, wield additional weapons and interact with friends and foes using amazing new expressions.\n\nIn this role-playing adventure game from Lionhead Studios, every action determines a characterâ€™s skills, appearance and morality. A characterâ€™s life story is created from childhood through adulthood and on to old age. As additional story and side quests await, so too does the path of righteousness, as well as the life of evil. With every choice, a character transforms into a reflection of his actions and decisions.

reviewText:
This game is pure nostalgic for me. If grown up with it. I played this game for the aight time now, and itÂ´s still outstanding.
The game has a lot of humor and looks (for the time it was made ) beautiful. You have the options to do whatever you like, but it's not a such a free game as Skyrim, GTA, ect. The places you explore are linear. That doens't matter in my opinion, in this way you dont waste your time on random exploring. There's always somthing at the end of your journey.
You can choose to be a hero, but you can also be a villain. But if you have played the game a couple of times, you know that the evil way is much more rewarding. Play this game and have Fun!!

reviewText:
Ok, It's Fable... We have mostly played it before. I picked this up simply to scratch a nostalgia itch. On the whole I found that it was good... still! Yes there are a couple of issues as it's an older game so the port hasn't aged particuly well, no controller support and as the magic system relied on three buttons on the xbox version it now relies on 2 (left and right mouse) which can make it a little difficult with all the scrolling to find the apropriate spell. you could of course get very wow style and have a million hotkeys buuut meh, its not really designed around it.

Anyway back on track, the port is actually good, 1080 supported (which looks quite lovely!)  AA is supported as well as some basic visual sliders and such. The only thing i found didnt work properly was the refresh rate, is seem to stick at 60fps, not terrible at all but i have a 120hz monitor sooo, well it would have been nice.

On to gameplay! Yes the game is flawed... it does feel a little like babby's first RPG"  but it has bags of character and you will remember your time with it. i found on my recent playthrough some more annoyances... such as indestructible barrels
date: having to run MILES to pick up rent and a slightly janky inventory. Seriously when you pick up a book you cant find it in your inventory.... its in your hero's logbook UNLESS it is a note/letter given by a non main story NPC and then it turns up in the "other" section of you inventory.  Yes the attack cycles will get repetative you will get bores of the 4 or 5 different unblockable "flourish" moves
recommended: ranged combat feels slow and you become super powerful very quickly. and then you feel like all the experience you have aquired is useless (it is) But with all that being said
hoursPlayed: Albion is a fantastic world to inhabit
voteText: a lot of thought went in to contextualising the world
helpfulPercent: everybody has a life that you can see being lead
votesHelpful: they will react accordingly... if you raid Oakvale
votesTotal:
and murder people (even as a good guy) you will find that for some time the inhabitants will cower and run away from you... even though you have a halo....

THE BOTTOM LINE.....
Flawed
votesFunny:
but fun and a relatively well done and useable port



"

reviewText: Roll up, roll up, come see the Fable series at its best. Fable was a great game, back in the day I borrowed my friend's XBOX just so that I could play this. While the sequels did take a few steps in the right direction, they also took a bunch of massive steps back.\n\nIf you've not played any Fable games, get this and give it a go. It's not the best RPG around, but it's certainly a good one. If you enjoy it, grab a friend and the sequel (which I notice isn't on Steam, but the third one is) for some good old co-op action.

reviewText: Fable: TLC was a well-made game when it came out for the original X-Box; even today, the aesthetics, the music, and the story are on par with the video-game industry standard today. The plot isn't that predictable, which one would assume it would be due to its age. The combat is very reminiscent of a hack-and-slash if you choose to play it so, but the magic gives you quite the variety. This is definately worth its price; I enjoyed every part of it, the original plot and the add-on quests included with this version.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Fable: TLC is a game I used to play as a kid. It's an absolutely fantastic RPG game. Compared to the other games in the Fable franchise this is gold and the others are dog â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. In Fable you get loads of moral choices which affect your character and the way other people in the world views you. Fable enjoys really enjoyable combat including a huge variety of spells. The variation of  weapons may be lacking, but there's a good variation of armour, clothes, tattoos and hairstyles. But the main part of the game is the amazing story and the great side-quests and the choices you have to make, there's load of things to do! (Unless you just rush the main quest which I don't suggest) Only problem I have is that the difficulty is really easy, and completing the game without ever dying isn't hard.\n\nThis game is an absolutely buy! You'll have hours of fun, and seeing at it is quite a old game, it's quite cheap as well!

reviewText: Ahhh, Fable. An amazing game, it has great RPG and action elements, great story telling and loads of interesting mechanics. If you've never heard of the Fable franchise then I advise you to get it as you will have hours of unguided fun. The game shapes around you, if you're evil, then your character will grow horns and turn more and more demonic with every evil action you commit. If you're good, then your character will glow with the essence of goodness. If you eat too much you become fat. This game is an awesome storytelling wonder, some may even consider it as the father of Action-RPG's. If you're still skeptical, look up some gameplay on Youtube, and decide then, you're missing out if you don't play this game.

reviewText: Picked this game up during the Winter Sale and I've got to say that this game is incredible.  I'm the first to complain about graphics and when I saw this game I was kind of put off but heard nothing but good things about it so I decided to try it out and I'm glad I did.\n\nThere needs to be more games like this one, this is a TRUE RPG, more of one than popular titles like Skyrim... in fact I had more fun playing this game than Skyrim.  I saw mechanics in this game that present day games don't even touch; the fact that your character's appearance changes depending on everything from your fighting style to the foods you eat or good/bad deeds you do is freakin genius and you just don't see that today.  If you love RPGs seriously pick this up.

reviewText:
It's quite fitting that the first serious recommendation I do for a game would be Fable: The Lost Chapters.

You know how some people tend to play Deus Ex whenever it's mentioned because of how much they love it? In this case, Fable is my Deus Ex. Ever since I played it on the Xbox in 2004. I was hooked.

The game truly gives you a feeling of connection with your character, as you play as him from a small child to an elderly, war-torn man. Although some characters are rather dull, most are well-done and well-written for the context of the game. Even when I was an evil â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ who slayed every villager in his sight, I still couldn't bring myself to killing certain characters.

The story itself is excellent, dropping you in the mystical land of Albion where beasts of all sorts roam. The main villain is revealed rather late in the game, giving you a chance to explore and understand the environment you were put into without being forced to fight a singular individual. I, personally, enjoy the setting of the game, pitting you in a medieval-esque surrounding.

The game gives you a nice sense of freedom when choosing your playstyle. You can be a stealthy archer, a brutish barbarian, a wise spellcaster, or a combination of them. I did a run using only fire spells, and another as a spell-archer. The possibilities aren't endless, but you have quite a bit of freedom in choosing how you want to play.

And to top all that off, the music is absolutely brilliant. Have a listen: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wUWEZ47-elQ

On some bad notes, though, the morality system seems rather extreme. The game sets every quest for you to become either some sort of saint, or a completely evil â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. To put it into an analogy, you're either giving candy to an orphan, or you're kicking said orphan in the teeth.

Almost all cutscenes use canned animations, which can be a bit of an eyesore later in the game, and of course there are graphical errors and glitches that might scare some people away; It's understandable, seeing as you can SEE UNDER THE CHARACTERS' EYELIDS.

The game is also a bit too easy. As long as you have a steady supply of potions that you can buy with gold that's easy to obtain, you can't die. If you really wanted to have a feeling of difficulty, you would need to throw out all of your resurrection vials and try to limit your potions. That's pretty much the only way to make this game harder than it is.

All bad points aside, I truly enjoy this game; even enough to call it my favourite game ever. I sincerely recommend this game to anyone reading this. It may not be the most immersive RPG in existence, nor could it stand up to the likes of Kingdoms of Amalur in gameplay, I still say you should give it a try by any means possible.

That being said, though, stay away from the sequels to this game.

reviewText: Fable: TLC was a well-made game when it came out for the original X-Box; even today, the aesthetics, the music, and the story are on par with the video-game industry standard today. reviewText: The game was first released on the original Xbox 10 years ago. Despite its age, the game holds up pretty well by today's standards. You can play as Evil or Good by making moral choices. The combat hasn't aged too well, but the combo system is still very fun. The game is mostly linear; however in-between main quests, you can choose to do side quests, explore around for treasures, or buy a house and marry someone. Visually colorful with a unique art direction. Musics are great and memorable. The story is simple and straightforward, but there is a lot of lore if you care to read the books and pay attention to what NPCs say. Overall a good RPG. It's humorous world, fun combo system, and exploration will give you a good 20 hours of Fable.

reviewText: The only GOOD Fable game for PC, Fable: The Lost Chapters. It is the only Fable game for PC worth buying and playing. The world of Albion feels alive and beautiful, full of secrets and legend. The landscapes are very well detailed and nicely put together, and the graphics still hold up quite decently despite its age. The soundtrack is incredible, and the voice acting is all quite enjoyable. There's tons and tons to do in this game, and even when you beat it, can continue to play after the endgame is complete (You just have to wait patiently through the credits without skipping them).\n\nSave your money, don't buy Fable Anniversary, buy THIS GAME instead. They are LITERALLY the exact same game, only this one wasn't horribly maimed and twisted into a piece of garbage.

reviewText:
I came in to this game as a heavy Elder Scrolls/Open Environment RPG player.
That said, the limited environment as long as it's expected. Didn't limit my experience.
I actually enjoyed the more confined setting as a nice change of pace.
The graphics may not hold up today to some, but to me they are above passable.
The combat I would say is the weakest link in this game.
I was put in to situations where NPCs would spam stun techniques which would lead me getting multi-hit and multi-stunned with out me even being able to give a simple movement command in response. Allowing a very frustrating experience.
Aside from this, which seemed to only happen against the Rock Trolls or larger enemies that used AoE the coimbat though limited and repetitive managed to keep my interest.
I am a huge fan of stories in games, and this story seemed a bit sterotypical and generic for a RPG.
Yet it kept my interest with the townsfolk around me commenting on my recent quests I have achieved/completed.

I would say this is for any RPG fan for a quick play through, or if you want another average to above average RPG to dive in to. I will say this is worth the 10$ price tag, but I would wait for a sale for a extra pick up, rather than a main purchase. If you were to do that, as I did. You may be pleasently surprised with this game.
7/10

reviewText:
Fable - The Lost Chapters is one of the best games I have ever had the pleasure to play, and I have played many many games I don't have many hours in the account but I've replayed it at least 3 times needless to say it's loads of fun and very addicting.

The game has a great story with good plot twists. The player (You) follows the life story of a little boy who loses everything and is taken in as a student of a Hero school then you can choose to live his childhood or not and that's all i'm giving out! Not gonna spoil the fun :)

The world itself is responsive to what you do and the Npc's react to what you have done, if you have been good they will be warm towards you, and you'l get a circle above your head like if you were an Angel, If you have been doing bad deeds ( like me) such as hiting people with sticks, kicking chickens etc XD, you'l grow horns and people will fear you and be cold towards you. But that can also be influenced by what type of armor you are wearing, some types of armor have an evil look" to them  causing people to be repulsed by it.

Another fact about the world is that it is not fully open world it's region locked

reviewText: An attractively unusal, enticing, and refreshing game. A must play for anyone searching for a fresh fruit from a familiar tree. Fable covers the basics anyone would expect from an RPG and adds comical and quaint ideas of its own. Gameplay is smooth and intuitive and the graphics are charming and timeless. The voice acting is superb, only adding more charm to the game. Don't listen to the hype on forums, anyone who has anything negative to say about this game ruined it for themselves by anticipating something this game wasn't meant to be. I recommend this game to anyone.

reviewText:
okay for those who dont want the long run. this game is awesome. with that odd british humor i personally love, a cool (though cliched) story line. the art-style is awesome. but with an odd camera and a bit clunky combat it isnt the best in the world.

but DEFINITELY pick this game up, i can simply spend hours and hours on this game, and once you get the hang of the combat it really isnt that bad. with extra tricks and so on, its quite nice to try and figure out these techniques to be better and so on so forth.

although the renowned good/bad system isnt at all what it was hyped to be, its still a nice feature, and there are alot of choices which influense what character you are trying to build, and although it doesnt impact the game much more than the occasional cheering/buuing its still nice, and since it doesnt influence the game too much, i cant really complain since its just a thing you can care about if you want to, its an option, not a requirement

the quests are great, although not very special, this is one of the few games where i can actually care about the side quests.

the bosses, although way too few, they can be quite fun, the wasp queen is quite nice and  Jack of Blades 	 is an amasing boss. when i say amasing though, i mean i enjoyed it quite alot.

so all in all, its an amasing game, with its querks, its far from the best, i enjoy it to hell, and i hope you will too, since this is a game i believe everyone should pick up at some point.

reviewText:
Brilliant, engaging, masterful,
These are the words i would use to describe The Fable series.
Then Great, Still engaging, Waning,

This game has a quality story, and the combat system is perceptive and user-friendly with many exciting mixtures of weapons and spells. NPC's effectively react to the personality of the player that is derived through several ethical choices  made throughout the story.

Keep in mind this game is fun, yet im not sure the repetative combat is worth the story.
HOWEVER If this is your first time playing Fable.....You'll play for days.

reviewText:
equal parts ambition met with cordial shallowness, fable is a flat oddity. mind you, its not a generic game, nor is it missing anything crucial on a macro scale. fable's problem is that it's severely undercooked. yet simplicity itself can be a virtue within a sphere of confidence. sometimes a basic expression is all that's required to get a point across. it is fable's hinted aspirations among its genre identity that breeds contempt, yet it is no issue with the game itself. from the very start, fable makes apparent that the experience is going to be humble and straightforward. although it works on realization, it's too hard to deny a contradiction of the premise as expected when compared to the actual function. a broad comparison that falls apart as easily as its made would be likening fable as a western legend of zelda. both games are humble and straightforward action hybrids with identical targeting systems, but one game is serious, and one game is not.

in fable and in ocarina of time, the protagonist is a hero of a long bloodline, whose struggle is an inevitable result of that bloodline. in zelda, this is serious business, but in fable, it is not. though it took a total reevaluation of every event in the game to get to this conclusion, truthfully it is evident from the beginning of the game. the expression system of this game, likely developed to allow interaction than anything Iâ€™m saying, can only function in an atmosphere of normalcy, unseriousness, and even ridiculousness. yet, though I say heroics in fable are par the course, every person in the world takes it in with awe and reverence anyway. itâ€™s an utter contrast, how unserious and whimsical the things you do are, and how great and magnificent theyâ€™re transposed on the world scale. eventually, the two ends meet, and the hero does things worth praising, and it further drives this rift. I think a work should properly separate what is serious and what is not and fable struggles mightily in that regard.

being good or evil is still treated with incredible importance. there are, of course, mundane acts that boost your karma either way. killing townsfolk makes you evil, while killing bandits and some monsters makes you good, among various other things, but consistency is not what I refer to. fableâ€™s plot ramps up into clearly selfish and unselfish choices coinciding the the plot. though your choices have little mention, it is true that youâ€™re allowed to do great good or great evil, and it shapes the tone of the story even if the choices arenâ€™t totally integrated into the plot development. the great contrast of the choices makes them significantly less effective if the player harbors little malice; to me there was a single choice and its foil, never amounting to much weight. those who enjoy acting out villainy will find fable more accommodating, I believe, because the sharp contrast will create more viable choices. to be mentioned, no other pretense is at stake. fable wouldnâ€™t work with morally gray choices, its charm is its exaggeration. if anything at all is successful in fableâ€™s narrative, it would be the grand moral choices.

now, to put it bluntly, the gameplay sucks. fable borrows from the beat â€˜em up genre ignorantly. its combat can be likened to prince of persia, which is the worst model on the planet for combat. block stops every attack with no repercussions for blocking, so if required, you can be invincible at any time. enemies annoyingly have the incredible block too, with no wind up or downtime on any of their attacks, making all fodder near identical. which is to say, unsatisfying and irritating. animations are awkward and contact comes with no good feeling or fanfare. a few lame hits in, the enemy will block. when youâ€™re blocked, or you successfully block, the heroâ€™s weapon will glow purple. the other attack button will let the hero do a slightly more damaging guard break attack that will knock the enemy down. unless you hit the enemy while itâ€™s down, itâ€™ll get up and begin blocking again. there are never any weak-tiered enemies; current level enemies will always take a few knockdowns before being defeated. battles only occur in mobs and waves, with the exception of two enemy types and boss fights. one of those enemy types is a flyer that has a limited window of vulnerability, the other and bosses have constant super armor. so, theyâ€™re annoying in different ways.

spells and ranged attacks canâ€™t be blocked. it goes without saying theyâ€™re the mainstay of your repertoire. arrows are boring, but cost no mana, cost nothing at all, so they are vastly more efficient. offensive spells come out instantly, with a few exceptions, but have bland particles and effects. there are utility and summon spells which I did not use myself, so I canâ€™t fully comment on, but considering the games difficulty and how quickly enemies were dispatched, theyâ€™re probably more effort than theyâ€™re worth. it doesnâ€™t matter how you fight, despite my criticisms. the only requirement to win is to have potions. theyâ€™re very cheap for being basically full heals. I donâ€™t know what revival potions do, because I didnâ€™t die, but I guess they revive you on the spot. my arsenal of 50 potions defeated the game.

easily the best part of fable is its level design. areas are distinct and there are no repetition. they are busy with detail, a careful labor. that being said, every single quest area in the game is a corridor. there are few change ups and theyâ€™re in the form of loops or alternate corridors, but the levels remain corridors. towns are, at least, more open affairs. theyâ€™re painstakingly detailed too, but there isnâ€™t much to do in them. not a lot to shop for with only 4 tiers of weapons and armors. you can play games at the inn or attempt to bed faceless people and thatâ€™s the extent of things to do in town. models are soft and rounded, built to look like toys instead of things. the style is a touch of unique, able to convey realism and fantasy. every character model in the game is ugly despite this. there arenâ€™t that many models either. the guys look like apes and the girls look like dolls. seeing the same ugly models everywhere starts to become distracting and annoying. even the main character is unattractive by default. fableâ€™s scenario design is ok. the main quest is a everlong chain of meniality and fetching until the plot drops, the sidequests are only terrible things like defend quests, escort quests, and timed quests.

overall fable is of poor quality. featuring embarrassing writing and voice acting, limited and blindly executed combat, and uninspired scenario. it has fantastic music and environment design, maybe top tier in both respects, so it isnâ€™t an absolute pain. it might as well be, though, as those aspects are passive quality. the irreverent simplicity of fableâ€™s world did not impress. I want bite with my satire or development with my seriousness, not a work that stops short of either. what fable does have going for it is a combination of things that cannot be had or found in any other game. itâ€™s partly to how npcs react to your character and definitely how it frames moral choices, but fable is an adventure all to itself. it being curious and an obvious work of passion is not enough to overcome its massive flaws. being interested in odd combinations, fable was enjoyable to a point, but I canâ€™t call it any more than a dead average title.

reviewText:
Fable - The Lost Chapters is truly one of the best RPGs ever. It covers and AMAZING story, alongside a bunch of really nice side-quests. Basically, you start the game as a young boy who dreams of greatness and you continue your journey through the vast land of Albion. Step by step you grow to be stronger, faster, smarter, and also older. Either you choose to be a mage, a warrior, or a rogue, you will end up to be the greatest hero of all, a Legend.

Now, the game has nice graphics (even though it was released in 2005 for PC), an AMAZING soundtrack, and one of the best, and most memorable voice actings ever. The worst thing about this game series is that they have failed to make the other Fable titles like this one.



10/10

reviewText:
Music 7/10- This game has a good soundtrack. Lots of memorable songs that help to describe the tension or calmness of a situation that the game places you in.

Gameplay 7/10- I got this game on the original Xbox, I loved the game then and I still do now, BUT there isn't much of a challenge to some of the major fights in the game. It might be that certain character builds are just TOO strong for the game or mabey I just played the game too much to even remember if it ever was difficult.

Story 9/10- The original game had a great story, one that starts off simple and slowly builds to the main character finding out about his family and it's secrets. This game also gives you the choice to either be a hero or a villian and decide the fate of Albion and its people.

Overall - Great game, if you're a fan of adventure rpgs then this game is a must buy. The game isn't too long but it is a fun game. However be warned that this game does have some minor bugs, for example on the final boss there is a choice you can make and it doesnt display the options, or in some parts the subtitles are shown but no dialoge is heard from the voice actors.

reviewText: Awesome game! I played a lot of this when it came out for the original Xbox and I can say that the overall story is still enjoyable to play after some time. You play as a newly trained hero who investigates about the whereabouts of his family after he is saved from his burning village. Thoughout adulthood, you learn magic and combat and have the choice to be good or evil. I would say the graphics are pretty good and orchestral soundtrack is great. However, I should mention that the game is pretty linear (there are sidequests though) and the game seemed a little easy since it was mostly hacking and slashing enemies.\n\nTo sum it up: great game with a good story. Game may seem a little easy, but if you like the satisfaction of hacking and slashing enemies, I say go for it.

reviewText:
Avaliable only on computer, unlike it's follow-ups, this PC game is still as good. My only faults are: that it was made in the dark ages of gaming when nearly all games had male protagonists, so there isn't any female option to play as; and that the people are fairly boring (none of the NPCs have as much character background as those in Fable 2 and 3, and you've no dog as a companion). The NPCs also follow you around with simple interactions and have hearts over their heads to indicate romanceable or not. It's not Fable 3 bad, but it's certainly not as good as Fable 2. Finally, clothing is fairly limited in this game unlike its successors, as the outfits of Knight, bandit, etc, do not have dye options. Plus, it also seems like a carry-on in the series; you're required to attain a bandit outfit from boxes in order to gain entry into the bandits' camp, which is very similar to Fable 3. However, to be fair, in Fable 3 you have the options of dying the outfit and changing your hairstyle more. Plus, you never actually meet any Knights in this game, or in the others for that matter, so that outfit is made practically meaningless. Basically, Fable 1 therefore mostly just has showy outfits for the player.

However, if you're a fan and want to find out how it began (I played 3, 2, and then 1), then this would be a good choice. The story-line is interesting, if a tad cliche, with the main character's family being separated by a bandit attack; you still have moral choices (good or bad actions, skinny or tubby, etc); there is certainly more information in Fable 1, as on the menu you can find how many houses you own to whether you're defined as hetro/homosexual through your interactions (information that isn't present in Fable 2 and 3!); you're more likely to gain scars and die during the battles in this one, as the gameplay is more difficult; and the graphics are quite good for a game this old.

Further, with the release of Fable 1 Anniversary on xbox360, the graphics are even further improved if you're more inclined to spend a little more and play on the console. The pixels are more noticeably defined on the console, but there are known glitches and the developers didn't add anything to the series. You would literally be spending your money on just lighter graphics. This PC version is just as good. In fact, it's better because it has more of a history.

So, all in all, the PC Fable 1: Lost chapters is a good game if you're looking for an intro into playing the later series or you're in want of playing a humorous game (the quests certainly do fit that bill).

reviewText:
I remember playing this game when I was younger and it was everything I ever dreamed about for a month atleast, back then it seemed like a long journey through the fable world, growing from a young scamp of a hero into a 70 year old bulked up, sword wielding legend. So naturally I jumped for joy when I saw Fable: The Lost Chapters on steam so I could relive the adventure... I completed the game in around 10 hours including the lost chapters section, if you loved or enjoyed the original fable back on Xbox then Im sure you would enjoy this just as much if not more but dont be sad if you complete the game within 2 seconds.

Graphics - Good (for its age)
Story - Epic (Best one out of all the Fables)
Gameplay - Does The Job (for its age)
Mechanics - Does The Job (for its age)
Memories - Brought Back
Overall - For the games age I'd give it a solid 8/10

reviewText: This game is a unique and one of a kind RPG that they developers were never able to recreate in it's sequals. It is really fun however it is exetremely short so if your looking for a game with more then 12 hours of gameplay then this game isn't for you. Also, a lot of music is reused in later parts of the game, which despite Fable's amazing sound track, does get annoying. Also the game is pretty easy considering the fact I can complete it without dying once throughout the playthrough. I still recommend this game, however. This is one of the only games besides GTA where you can randomly kill villagers for no reason, and you do get more gameplay if you try to find all the secrets without looking them up on the internet.

reviewText:
WHAT CAN I SAY...... This is by far the best of the series, this game is full of magic, revenge and compassion as you start as a young boy waiting to avenge the death of his family.... This game is full of decision making which affect your overall outcome.... will you be a feared hero or a loved one, will you have horns coming out your head or surrounded by butterflys?? It's all up to you.... the story telling is remarkable, the creatures and characters are fantastic, the combat system is very easy to master and not all over the place like League of legends and other magic power inspired games....

Once you have finished the storyline, you are free to keep playing and unlocking the other secrets of Albion.... I would still pay $20 for this gem....Warning....be prepared to lose a few days in front of your computer.... If I was to say anything bad, I'd say that the graphics are getting a little old...but that's it!!!

Overall I give this game a 10/10...it's a classic and it's just too good!!!

reviewText:
Every time I play Fable I'm pleasantly reminded as to just how timeless it really is. It's so damn good in my opinion that at least every 2 years I find myself playing it again, just to re-experience it and all of its stellar contents. In my opinion it's way up there in what I'd consider one of the best RPG's - if not one of the best games - of all time. If you haven't played it before, buy it and find the time to. You won't regret it if you're interested in good video games. I'll preface in saying that I've played this game far more outside of Steam, on both PC & Xbox, so I've more hours played this than what my profile suggests.

The amount of dynamic freedom Fable offers you is unprecedented anywhere else even now. 10 years on, I'm still surprised by how much I'm allowed to do. Infiltrating a bandit camp? You can either shoot the guards to pass, or sneak in-between them. Further in, you then need to retrieve a uniform; which then allows you access to the base camp. But how do you proceed to the Boss's location? You can choose to kill all the bandits in sight, drawing out the elites, opening your passageway. How about you release captive slaves as a diversion, hire a group of assassins to do the work for you, OR acquire a pass from a shady bandit hiding in a dark corner for 1000 gold pieces. Which you can then kill him to retrieve your money. Or just skip giving the part where you pay him. And it doesn't indicate to you these options - it leaves it for you to find them.

You've got all of the game's tight mechanics, and then on top of that it shoves this titanic amount of meta-content. Visit bars to play games like Blackjack, Pairs and a table-top golf-esque game called Coin Flick. Assist traders with their passage through the woods, seek out silver keys to open locked chests or pursue a treasure trail. Go fishing. Dig up some loot. â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ some â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥es that you pick up from your nearby Inn. Oh, and CHICKEN KICKING, â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥.

There's just so much to love. The sense of culture is hilarious; the attention to detail, consuming. The story, soundtrack and characters are memorable ones, too, and after finishing The Lost Chapters - the game's rather large and only expansion, from which this edition gets its namesake - for my first time this weekend, I can easily say Jack of Blades is certainly one of the most appealing antagonists I've seen in a video game.

I could write about this game for ages. One of the highest recommendations I could give for any video game out.

TL;DR: If you are one of the few that haven't played Fable, go out and buy it. It's a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing awesome game.

reviewText:
Fable: The Lost Chapters
Fable is one of the first M games I had ever been allowed to play when I was younger, and I believe that even now, it has aged gracefully. In Fable, it is simply astounding to the amount of interactions you can have with people. Sneer at them, scare the crap out of them, and children will run in terror at your approach. Or, become the saint that all love and respect, and give everyone a gift or two. Or, give 'em the middle finger and tell 'em to â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ off. Then say sorry. Then ask a gay man to marry you. Reputation is everything in this game, be you good or evil, a good reputation for being good or evil is still a necessity. Or, live between the lines, but there are times that playing around with your alignment is not the way to go, and only one choice can be made. That choice, however, is entirely up to you.
While the game does not entirely match up to some of the graphics of today, this game looks very beautyful and full of life, or death, especialy for it's time. The gameplay is very simple as well, and combat against multiple enemies can be fun, easy, very action packed once you get used to it. The replay value is actualy suprisingly high for the kind of game it is, and I'll tell you, I played this game on the XBOX dozens of times, each time telling myself I would become a different person, and each time, I found out something new about the game.
I will say that if there is anyone out there who wishes to test their fantasy of a Hero or Villian, come along and experience the game that changed the way games were made.

9.5/10

reviewText:
It's taken me about 8 years to get around to it, but I've finally mustered up the desire to beat Fable: The Lost Chapters - and it's taken me around 10 years to beat EITHER version of Fable. It was my first (quasi-)RPG on my first game console; so yes, I do have quite a few fond memories of this game in my youth. Does that mean that this game gets a rose-tinted reccomendation, free from the burden of actual critique? Far from it.

In terms of tone and presentation, Fable: The Lost Chapters is unique. It's one of the few fantasy settings in a video game I can think of that doesn't take much influence from Tolken: while some of the more tropey fantasy creatures such as Trolls and Nymphs are present, there are quite a few original creations, too. The artstyle and general world design echoes more traditional fantasy, giving the impression that one is, yes, in a fable. Top that off with tounge-in-cheek writing, a fantastic soundtrack by Russel Shaw, and vocal talent that is evidently from creator company Lionhead Studio's home town of Guildford, England, and Fable feels extremely fresh more than 10 years later.

However, the mirror-sheen production values can't hide a game that is, for lack of a better word, pretentious. Every mechanic, encounter, and story element is played up to be grandiose and epic in scale, but after the first few hours, the game clearly is clearly struggling to swim to the deep end of the pool.

The game's most notable feature, the morality system, is represented by good boy" and "bad boy" scale (note: may not actually be what they are called in-game)
date: and the extent of how much the game changes boils down to horns or a halo on your characters head

hoursPlayed: seriously). Most good boy points are aquired by saving people from attackers; most bad boy points are acquired by killing every non-combatant in sight. Even during major
voteText: story-influencing events

The system is so arbitrary and easily-manipulated that you can go from villian to hero in a couple binary choices' time. Worried about a hard choice? Don't worry

You can get married! Except there is very little reason to unless you want to get underpowered weapons gifted to you from time to time. Prices vary between shops
