reviewText:
NOT CONTROLLER READY! WTF MICROSOFT?! COULDN'T YOU PORT YOUR CONSOL GAME TO THE PC WITH GAMEPAD MAPPING?!?!?!?
I have yet to play the pc version, but after finding this out, I am turned off to play Fable: The Lost Chapters for the pc.

*EDIT 3/26/2014*

So I decided to give Fable a chance and so far playing with a mouse and keyboard is not so bad. Keep in mind though that I just started playing so I have yet to have any combat. I just wanted to say that Key  and Mouse isn't as bad as I thought.

*EDIT 3/29/2014

So I have been playing Fable: The Lost Chapters for a while and I feel like I must note that the game is great ALTHOUGH I do run into some difficulties due to where the actions are mapped. You might have two actions mapped to the same key, so you end up doing things that would didn't want to do. I thought that it was just me not being used the Keyboard and Mouse, but I still notice that I am getting actions twisted. I just want to make one thing clear thought, this is not game breaking. The game is still as wonderful as i remember. With added content waiting for me to explore, I am anticipating what I am going to encounter next!

*EDIT 4/4/2014

This will be my final edit for Fable: The Lost Chapters.
After playing Fable for like the millionth time (probably 5th time), I have to say that i did enjoy the new content. The Lost Chapters added more to the mythos behind the game and I did feel like I wanted to know more. Something else that The Lost Chapters (TLC in short) gives you is a somewhat better conclusion than the original. Although I feel like they could have done a lot more with this expansion. In a way, it feels like its what the original game SHOULD have been rather than purchasing TLC again in stores.
I know than when people first played this game, one of the main complaints was that it was a really short game, but I dont know, I clocked in with my 5th play through at around 18 hours, and im typing this right after I finished the game, no back tracking.
Fable has a world that has SO MUCH potential, but the way it presents itself in the game seems as if it was half â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, almost as if it was a blast talking about it, but the effort wasn't put into it. The way I see Fable is just a greeting to the world of Albion.
Game play on the computer was difficult at fist. I had a lot of trouble getting my character to do what I wanted since some keys are mapped along with other actions, but the issue was resolved when I mapped the magic activation and exp orb gathering to the mouse thumb keys. Remaping my keys made the gameplay a lot better.
Fable is a game that is a must play, wether you are new to the series or played the sequels. I recommend when playing this that you take your time, listen to what everyone (with a green glow) has to say. and explore the world.

reviewText: Fable is a groundbreaking roleplaying-adventure game from Peter Molyneux, in which your every action determines your skills, appearance, and reputation. Create your life story from childhood to death. Grow from an inexperienced adolescent into the most powerful being in the world. Choose the path of righteousness or dedicate your life to evil. Muscles expand with each feat of strength. Force of will increases with each work of wit. Obesity follows gluttony, and skin tans with exposure to sunlight and bleaches bone-white by moonlight. Earn scars in battle and lines of experience with age. Each person you aid, each flower you crush, and each creature you slay will change this world forever. Fable: Who will you be?

reviewText:
Very good game. You can choose between good and bad. This also changes your skin from godlike with nimbus on your head to devilface with 2 horns on your forehead.

If you only follow the mainquests the game is a bit short but if you try all quests and if you play it 2 times (good/bad) it has a moderate playtime.

You start the game as kid and you will grow up while playing. Also with skin changing and a growing beard and changing haircolor. Story is good, gameplay is good. Game has a nice moneytrick which seems very planned by the developer.

I have played it 2 times for testing both sides and the story really changes a bit, every side has his pros and contras. Check it out yourself. ;D

9/10

reviewText: I think this game may have been great in 2004, but I never played it back then. Nowadays I don't like it mostly because of it's combat system. You have to score as many consecutive hits as possible without getting hit yourself, to get the combat multiplier up. Unfortunately when I see anyone attack it's far too late to get a block up/dodge. You can kill things this way, but it feels like button smashing to me. The flying nymphs who constantly summon melee fighters to attack you are incredibly annoying, as you can only hit them with your bow with the target lock on system, which i could not get to lock on to the enemy i wanted to attack but instead the nearest enemy, which was not the nymph but all the summoned melees.\nThe good/evil choice system is interesting, i just couldn't find a motivation to do anything evil. I thought the hero suffered enough evil in his youth and got rescued by good ones to feel that good is the only path for him and there are no great rewards for being evil. BUT it's still better than Fable III which i could only stand for 2 hours before deleting it.

date: for what it was to me playing it in 2016.\n\nTL;DR: I wanted to like this game a lot but overrall I couldn't get over how clumsy it is. I personally cannot recommend it to anyone. I'm sure it was more worth playing at its time
recommended: but in 2016 you have so many better RPGs at hand and this is not one of those timeless classics
hoursPlayed: which I truly thought it would be.\n\nTo start
voteText: the save system is an absolute disaster. You can manually save the game while you play
helpfulPercent: but when you're in a quest you can "hero save" which saves your items and stats but not your quest progress. In any case
votesHelpful: both of them are extremely problematic. It's not actually consistent what saves and what doesn't
votesTotal: and the game is in no way smart about making sure it saves properly. For example

commentsCount: but it remembered that I had used the items required in the quest.... so basically

column18: occasionally breaking an entire storyline altogether. This alone is a game breaker.\n\nNow to combat. Fighting against one enemy

column20: you can hack and roll and block to be a formidable fighter. As soon as 2+ enemies come at you
column21: it all falls apart. Blocking becomes useless (actually
column22: blocking performs inconsistently to begin with). The target system is supposed to let you switch between targets but doesn't realistically let you do that in a helpful way. So to get through a wave of baddies without being seriously hurt
column23: you need to use an overpowered spell and consume 10 mana potions? That sounds like a cheap exploit
column24: not like enjoyable combat. In many ways
column25: this game rewards you for overpowering easy spells and punishes you for trying to take part in actual melee or ranged combat.\n\nThe enemies seem to be very inconsistent. You will face an enemy and find it easy to mow down
column26: then moments later you'll come across another one and it seems to have infinite health. I don't know what the basis is
column27: exactly. When you run into some bandits on the way to a destination and it takes 5 minutes to get rid of them in the same repetitive chop chop chop get knocked over drink mana put up shield chop chop chop sequence
column28: it just becomes tedius. You can recruit some expensive mercenaries to help you

column30: each with a totally random mystery amount of health
column31: swarming me while my auto-target aims at my mercenary or the person I'm supposed to be escorting to safety. What? How does that help me in any way?\n\nThere are two cosmetic mechanics in the game that are really cool to a point but become rather irritating. First of all

column40: and gulping down mana potions if you do get hit.\n\nThe characters in this game are f***ing irritating. There were a few funny moments that genuinely made me laugh

column50: making everything to do with currency in the game entirely meaningless. Why should I do quests boasts (an interestnig feature where you bet money on accomplishing quests with special limitations) if I can just make all that money from a game of memory? Why wouldn't I just buy all the best armor there is if I can get all the money I need at any time? Any progression pertaining to the spending of money is undermined. column57: or overpowered spells in order to play the game and do well. If you want to actually play the game in the way it presents itself and that has meaning to it

column59: I'm glad I finally got around to playing a game from the Fable series just so I could check it out

reviewText:
Now, I'm not one of those people who had this game ruined by the hype that ensued around its release, nor does this game offend me, I'm just voicing what I feel is so problematic with this game. Fable is essentially an action RPG, so I'm going to hold it to my standards of an action RPG, I feel that is only fair.

Since Fable is an action RPG I guess I'd be best to start with its RPG elements. My biggest complaint is how shallow they actually are, they make Pokemon (the single player aspect that is, so the fanboys stop ripping my head off) look super in depth and complex. No thought needs to be put into leveling your character to make sure he can face the challenges ahead. The fun of RPG elements is having to make a tough call on what needs to be leveled to keep your character ready for the fights ahead. The thing is you can essentially max out the levels in every skill tree in one playthrough, this lowers replay value significantly, and eliminates the decision making aspect that makes RPG elements so enjoyable. Other action RPGs like Fallout New Vegas have max levels, so you have to making a decision as to what you're actually going to level up, this ensures the player isn't mindlessly filling all the bars on the stats screen, keeps the game interesting. All of the RPG elements are basically tacked on, and have little to do with your success in combat in any way more than how much damage you do, and how much defense you have

So if the RPG elements are rather shallow, the game must fall back on its action, or combat. The combat in Fable is rather uninteresting to be quite honest. It has little depth to it as well, as it ends up being constantly clicking to keep hitting the enemy in the face, shooting the enemy or blasting an enemy wth some spell. *Correction* Enemies do have weaknesses, but I went the whole game without noticing a real difficulty jump from ignoring these weaknesses, rendering them pointless, since they failed to add complexity to the way I played the game. Enemies don't have stats that effect the damage you do to them, like if they wear armor or are immune to certain spells or elements or weapons. So little thought is required from the player to be successful in combat. The combat is so simple that it grew quite repetitive and monotonous very quickly. An in depth RPG system and nuanced combat would give players something to dig into, invest time in and master, but this game plays more like a really uexciting beat 'em up than an RPG.

Of course there is player choice and morality, which has become a near industry standard in action RPGs. Just like the combat and level system, the element of choice is just as simplistic. Most situations have very black and white morality involved, which holds back a players freedom to construct a character that is anything other than a saint or a demon. While you are given choices, you never face serious consequences for these choices, so why should they matter to the player? One choice bothers me in particular, where *SPOILERS* you can choose to put on the mask or not at the end of the game. Instead of using some kind of prompt or better yet presenting this choice to me through the gameplay, the choice happens during a cutscene, and the way they handle it baffles me to no end. Why would you click the mouse to NOT put on the mask? Wouldn't you NOT click the mouse to NOT put on the mask? How is a player supposed to know it isn't just a regular old cutscene, this isn't conveyed to the player on any level.

Fable highlights my problem with morality systems in general. Fable tells the player what is right and what is wrong, so the player doesn't have to think about this morality for themselves. The morality system should have been a hidden aspect of the game, working behind the scenes, so the player doesn't know they are being judged on a moral scale. If the player was making morality choices throughout the game without being told which options are good or bad, their actual moral alignment would come to light, and the game would make people think about the decisions they made. But since this game tells you immediately the good and evil options, people will choose what the game tells them is good or bad rather than what they actually believe, this morality system reveals nothing about the player, and has little bearing on the direction the story actually goes. People's true moral standing comes most to light when morality isn't in their thoughts at all. Since the morality system doesn't make me question my moral alignment, or have any serious consequences story wise, why should I care about making these decisions? I make decisions in the real world because I am concerned with their consequences.

This game gets a lot of recognition for its charm, I'd credit the game's tone. While the story, characters and setting are not exactly super compelling, especially on RPG standards, the tone is handled quite well. The tone of this game lends Fable a pretty memorable atmosphere. The most prominent example of the game's use of tone is right from the beginning when a light hearted intro is suddenly cast aside by a quite jarring, uncomfortable and expectation flipping tonal shift as tragedy strikes the main character. This intro is a nice kick-off to the game's plot, and gets the player ready to start the game. Unfortunately charm alone can't hold up a game.

I feel Fable, while not as offensively simplistic as its sequels, is still too lacking in sophistication on a gameplay standpoint for me to consider it a solid action RPG, and I cannot recommend it to anyone.

reviewText:
Overall the game is pretty addictive and fun to play.
The only thing that is extremely frustrating to the point that it pisses me off is the
way the enemies attack later in the game. You have to be super on point when it comes to blocking and moving.
Otherwise you will just get hit repeatedly and it will affect your multiplier quite often.
In the part of the game with all of the skeletons, they pop up from under the ground right before you and attack you
over and over and over and over right as they come up. You can't block it and you can't avoid it unless you
slowly creep along the pathways and hallways. That is extremely stupid in my opinion and a total waste of health
that you can't avoid losing.
Other than that, the game is pretty fun. I have played through as a good character, now I'm playing through as evil.
Once I'm done, I won't be playing it ever again. It's sorely lacking on player experience.

reviewText: I played hours upon hours of this game when I was younger, closer to it's release. Upon replaying it, I still enjoyed myself, but wasn't horribly impressed. The morality mechanics, feel dated, heavy handed, and ultimately pointless, and the story isn't anything particularly special. This is by no means a bad game, the gameplay still holds up fairly well, particularly the character building, but if you don't have any nostalgic attachment and are looking for a variable RPG experience, you'd be better off picking up Skyrim, Mass Effect, or KOTOR instead.

reviewText: About the worst camera work I've ever seen being put into an action/rpg game. The moment you enter any sort of cave your entire field of view starts shooting everywhere. The friendly AI is trash, the enemy AI is trash, and the only way you might ever die by their hands is if you get swarmed by them like a bunch of ants. And that happens a lot, pretty much anytime when you're in a quest. I'm not going to comment on the voice over since everyone has different preference on that one, but it does get repetitive quickly. I'll say one thing though, for a PC port it runs rather smoothly, so I guess that's a plus.

reviewText: This is a game which could have been decent (even though it really shows its age). Unfortunately, the user interface is very poorly designed. To add insult to injury, the save system is probably the most idiotic that I have ever seen. You can save only very rarely in predetermined points (that you don't always know about). If any mission is a failure, the only option is to redo it until it succeeds. Ignoring failures is not even an option. The silliness of the moral" system is not better either. There are no moral quandaries: just choices between "saving the kitten" and "crushing the kitten with your boots". Stupid. Poor design."

reviewText: No controller support on a game that was made on a console with controller support. Use xpadder I guess. Nothing new has changed other than that on this game if you were one of the millions of people that bought this game more than a decade ago on the promise from its boneheaded creator that it was gonna be the most amazing thing out there with so many features (that sadly weren't in the game). You run around killing monsters, following a moderately good RPG story and do other stuff as well. Such as collecting, playing mini games and choosing wheter to be a good or bad guy. Most games do what it does better and just to name one around the time that this game out was Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind. The Knights of the Old republic game also  was better on the rpg aspect and really letting you feel like you're making good choices or bad choices. The second fable to me personally was a better investment than this, but if it happens to go on sale you should buy it. After all we here at Steam believe in racking in as many games on our library and completely ignoring them when other games we will ignore as well go on sale.

reviewText: I wish there was a I liked it but I don't think it's worth getting" option. I've played through this game three times
date: two to completion; and the third time is why I don't recommend getting this game. My first time I played a warrior
recommended: the game was a piece of cake. I had like two points in mage and so when I got to the point where you had to used ranged -- it was slow and I went through a ton of healing potions but doable.\n\nThe same thing with playing a mage. If anything after a few levels it was beyond easy to run around and basically wipe the floor with anything that came close. There's lots of threads that talk about how OP mage is for good reason
hoursPlayed:
the game is a cake walk with it.

But the third playthough I wanted to do a pure archer. Only turns out you can't. There are certain quests where you will get mobbed even trying to be extremely sneaky and one shot people with max range -- certain quests essentially require close combat.

I don't mind when a certain combat style or class
voteText: is overpowered and much easier to play through. In fact that's sometimes a plus; but to have a whole class be nearly impossible to win with does bother me. I don't actually think you can complete the final boss battle as an archer -- it's again structured to give an advantage to mages and warriors who can take damage close combat style.\n\nMaybe I'm missing something
helpfulPercent: because there's certainly gear and setups for all three combat styles
votesHelpful: but it just feels like range is really underpowered throughout.\n\nOverall
votesTotal: you really do become insanely powerful proportionally quickly. The later levels were honestly overly easy
votesFunny: even with the additional content added
commentsCount: I still breezed through it all. Wearing plate as a warrior you're essentially invulnerable; and you can get several swords that can single shot almost everything. There's no real challenge to the game.\n\nThat all being said -- I consider it "adventure game lite" in that it's short enough to beat in an afternoon and have seen all the content and feel satisfied that you played a whole game. Excluding silver key and demon door hunting there's about 7 hours of content per playthrough
column16: which makes in a nice fix for wanting to play a RPG but not wanting to invest 100+ hours in an elder scrolls game.\n\nI would say it was kiddie -- but there's enough sexual innuendoes

column18:
that make it rated-M and so it just falls into a category where it feels like something I would let a kid play as introduction to the genre but it has moments of being a little to edgy for that.

Pros
+ Easy difficulty
+ Good length

Cons
- Unmemorable story
- poorly balanced combat triangle

reviewText: The game was one of my faves when it was released. Unlike most RPGs, there were immense amounts of choices on how to build, and essentially, how to play as well. There is a main storyline, of course, and a presecribed path to take, but the game does sell on its promised choose your destiny format.\n\nThat said, gameplay is quite broken in general, and takes adjustment if you wish to scrape by without the broken aspects. For instance, you can make money simply buy buying and selling stuff to the same shopowner, as his stocks of items fluctuate the cost. Additionally, the most broken skill in the game is Physical Shield, as it not only keeps you from taking any damage at all, but you don't get thrown around, and you never lose your precious combat multiplier, so long as you chug mana potions, and that helps break the game wide open for you. But, in general, any character can grind to the point of being all-powerful, with some time invested, of course, as any build path is open for any character, as even though Being good" or "Being bad" does influence your skill pool minimally
date: it's even more minute because fluctuating between good and bad is not difficult (especially for being bad...).\n\nAll that aside
recommended: the game was pretty much the first game to give a hero any type of plotline choices that I saw
hoursPlayed: and I must commend them for that. However
voteText: the game has a poor look for being released on Steam nowadays
helpfulPercent: and only diehard plot enthusiasts or general gamers who want to experience it all will enjoy this. I had to buy it for old time's sake
votesHelpful: and while it has managed to accrue a bit of playtime
votesTotal: I don't see many out there enjoying this for what it's worth in this age of gaming. I really don't know of anything like Fable still
votesFunny: and I enjoyed it more than Fable III (haven't played the others...)
commentsCount: but getting through the early game will be hard to weather through to get to the better parts of the plotline and become strong enough to feel less than some shrimpy character at times. In my opinion
column16: casters are very underpowered
column17: partly because Physical Shield is so overpowered
column18: and will sap your mana if you don't kill things fast enough as a caster. The other paths get so much more powerful
column19: and I don't see why you'd even bother. Still a huge step in the right direction for a choose-your-own-path type adventure
column20: but there is still a clearly prescribed path
column21: like any adventure with an adversary. It just has good areas you can stray from the path a bit
column22: and they will effect your destiny in various ways.\n\nI checked... I played it on Steam for 2nd most hours compared to any reviewer
column23: and that's not all that much... I don't know what that could mean for certain
column24: but I'd guess that the majority of reviewers who upvoted it are in it for the nostalgia. It was a good game in its heyday
column25: but I believe that the strengths of this game would be overshadowed too much by its weaknesses in today's gaming environment

column27: but while this one is on the fence for me

reviewText:
i'm only going to do this because i didn't have a good experience with this version of the game. hpoefully the remake of it will be better, but if you loved this game with a controller, you won't like this version of it.

this version og the game, i noticed had problems, maybe it's my computer or just the old hardware it ran on.
but there are physics glitches in cutscenes that really jar the experience, and i don't remember if it was this bad on the console but it kind of hurt after a while.
i also had this weird lag in menus, so it'd take a bit of time to get the mouse over what you wanted to click on. i also noticed lots of flisckering with teh lighting in ares of the game.
one of the worst parts of this though, is thta there isn't any controller support, so you have to put up with the weird keys to play the game. i tried rebinding keys, but important ones i wanted to bind couldn't be changed from where they were set.
i'd think all of these things really made me not care about how i played the game. i did still have fun though. i went as far as to play all of the story and the dlc, because i wanted to have a full feel of how it ran on pc and not give up and give it a bad review.
personally, i'd say, if you really wanted this, that you could take your chances with the remake, since it looks like it's more promising, and i hpoe it'll run better than this. but if you want this, since it's cheaper, don't let anyone tell you not to.
if you get this as a gift from a friend, like i did, thank them and have fun.

reviewText:
Fable Anniversary contains and improves on all the content of The Lost Chapters.

Pros: Story, Gameplay
Cons: Anniversary

Fable stands out among numerous RPGs with more than a fantastic story and characters but gameplay revolving around the  choices the player makes to create his or her character.  The combat is fantastic, supported by a number of possible paths and styles, from summoning to sabers.

However, Fable Anniversary contains all the content of Fable - The Lost Chapters but also sports improves visuals, sounds, interface, and balance.  For both fans and newcomers alike, Anniversary is the version to get.

8/10

reviewText:
This game shows it's age. Not just in graphics, but in plotline. Maybe the voice acting and side quest mechanics were interesting at the time, but now? Meh. Specific points:

Marketed as a game where you could have influence in the world, but....
-You can be mayor. What does it mean to be mayor? Nothing. You don't do anything, noone reacts.
-You can own property. What does it mean to own property? Not much. You can upgrade the furnishings, hang trophies on the wall, and collect rent. And then never go back, because why would you?
-You can get married. Find one of the many nameless NPCs and stand in front of them to show off your manly pectorals. Then throw a ring at them. You now have access to the sex scene, which is a fade to black with suggestive voice acting. Never interact with your wife again.
-You can be good or evil. What's the difference? Halos or demon horns. You could slaughter the innocent one day, vanquish the wicked the next, and that's totally fine.

The running theme is that none of these decisions impact the story greatly. You can occasionally choose: kill this dude" or "don't kill this dude." That'll affect 2 or 3 scenes. Basically doesn't matter.

Not sure what to say about the core gameplay. I found it very easy
date:
but YMMV.

Fable - The Lost Chapters, Released on Steam 2011, Copyrighted 2005...

reviewText: Not bad but not great, though it is only 10 bucks so you're getting what you pay for. This game feels pretty restrictive by today's standards in terms of what you can do and where you can roam. date: trade goods for profit etc. and the character customisation

reviewText: A long time ago, when this game first came out, there were a bunch of people telling me how awsome this game was.  Originally it was only for the XBOX.  Years later it was on Steam and I got it cheap.  I have played it for 20 hours, but I did not finish it.  I finished the main quest, but once I got to the expansion part, I just couldn't make myself play it any more.  The people who made this game sure had some strange Ideas such as the color of your clothes causing NPC reactions, what kind of mustache actually matters, etc...\n\nAnyway the UI is horrid.  The mechanics are somewhat simplistic.  I do not care about any of the NPCs in the game.   Perhaps at the time it was revolutionary, but it has not aged well.   It did spawn 2 sequals.  I am not sure why.  I can't reccomend it, however if you are bored and this is very cheap and you go in with low expectations, you might be pleasntly surprised.

reviewText:
First played this game on console around the time it came out. I was young and stupid, and ended up selling all of my clothing to the Guild shop vendor then wondering why I was running around naked. I quickly became better at this game, and learnt everything there is to know about it, and it's been keeping me entertained for years. All together I've probbaly played this game for about 1000 hours.

The gameplay is fairly smooth, and the controlls aren't hard to get used to, although I personally enjoyed them a lot more on console. But if you're looking for a challenge, then this game might not be for you, although that can depend on how hard you make it for yourself. If you regularly level up and get the best weapons you can (which can be found pretty early) you'll blast through this game no problem, but if you stick with an iron sword and rarely level up, you'll have a bit of a tough time. You could always try and play through this game on the unnoficial hardcore" mode and never level your character.

The graphics are part of this game's charm. The textures are well done
recommended: and the lighting is pretty nice to look at as well. The music is decent
hoursPlayed: but I found it's stuck with me over the years
voteText: while the actual game sounds are nicely done as well. No low quality
helpfulPercent: and they sound like they actaully fit with each action.\n\nThis game is pretty short
votesHelpful: if you do just one playthrough. You'd be lucky if you got more than 17 hours out of it
votesTotal: but there are tons of choices to make throughout the game
votesFunny: so there's a bit of replayability. There's a few easter eggs around as well
commentsCount: which are always nice to see.\n\nThat's my review for Fable: The Lost Chapters. Hope you like it and hope you enjoy Fable as much as I do! :)"

Hands down the Best game that introduces morality. Lost chapters is extremly awesome because of the bonus boss fight at the end! I have played this game and passed it over 50 times, evil, good, strength focus/ magic focus / skill focus and such, and only recent purchased it for pc.
This is the best fable game, fable 2 and 3 are a joke and i was heart broken when i played them.
NO other fable game has bosses and a variety of inventory like this one.
On top of that, the British humor is always a plus since it can be dry at times, and i love dry humor.
I really wish there were more games like this, unfortunately this is the only one of its caliber. I'd play it again and again, and the silent protaganist makes it feel like  you are the hero/villain.

reviewText:
Fable is a game about one thing - beating the snot out of everything in sight.  Many will say that it is supposed to be about choice, but in reality the choices don't matter aside from giving you specific weapons (or constantly having the village guards on you about simply existing).  Beat up enemies, search for relics to increase your power, do quests to increase your influence, follow the storyline.  Rinse, repeat.

In terms of environment I'd prefer a game similar to Dragon Quest 8 or The Elder Scrolls for this type of gameplay.  The world is segregated by zones and paths between them rather than an open world you are able to get lost in, quickly quashing any feeling of freedom in exploration you would otherwise have in the game.

Freedom in building your character, on the other hand, is much closer to the other end of the spectrum.  You can play as a melee weapon strength user, a ranged weapon skill user, or a physics-bending will user.  Or, if you want to put another 100 or so hours into the game, you can do all three and make yourself nearly untouchable.  Tons of melee weapons, ranged weapons, and spells make any of the three viable - but ultimately you'll be building these up by beating the snot out of everything in sight.

reviewText: Fable been one of the games that I have played all throughout my childhood. It has been a stable game that I have come time and time again to relive the story and my childhood. The fighting, the magic, the wonder, it has always been a part of my imagination, and I sometimes wonder where my video game habits would like if I never played Fable 1 on the Xbox.\n\nNow, time has come to pass for this game to come onto the PC scene with more of a storyline at the ending with slightly improved graphics overall. This game did not disappoint. Having played this sparingingly, I still have as much fun as ever when I am playing this game. Have I reached the storyline at the end? No. Has this game been fun, even though I haven't reach that climax. Yes.

reviewText: I remember buying this for the first time on XBox just like it was yesterday, The fantasy and nostalgia factor is high. For 10$, Honestly you can't go wrong. reviewText: Let me put it this way. It's not so good that I don't feel that twinge of pain when I see how many hours I've played...but it's good enough that that doesn't stop me from playing more. The story is fairly interesting, the visuals are decent (better than Fable Anniversary in my opinion), the voice acting is decent, and despite the simplistic good/evil moral choices (save your sister or kill your sister?) I've found that there are far more than two ways to play this game. I've finished the game four times. One character is now an 80 year old man covered in faded tattoos and scars, glowing with goodness, and possessing every skill in the game. Another is an scrawny, 20 year old with nothing but a sword and a magic shield spell (and I mean nothing else; he runs around in his underpants...and still can marry any girl/guy he wants) that wouldn't look like an adventurer if he wore armor made from balverine bones. I picked this game up on sale and I don't regret it one bit. If you like RPG's, just play it. You'll only regret it the third or fourth time.

reviewText: A classic RPG released on PC with extra content as Fable: The Lost Chapters. This is arguably one of the most immersive western RPG games ever. It's famous for its customization and immersion of the player into the world. You can do just about anything in the world of Albion as your choices have an impact on the world around you. If you perhaps choose to get married and retire your life of heroics for the life of a familyman, nothing's to stop you! Almost anything is imaginable in the world of Albion as you can choose to become a heroic warrior or an evil warlord as you set upon a path that will affect everything around you in one way or another. Recommended for any fan of the RPG genre or anyone who likes immersion in their games.\n9/10

reviewText: Awesome game! One of the best RPG's I've played! Character growth is the most amazing part, can't compare it to any game of this age. The actual story is also really deep and governed by the characters personal choises. Even the choices the character takes define how others see him, physicaly and individualy. The only negatives could be that there are set paths to follow with a sizeable movement area, and that there is no character creation at the beginning. The character is a boy that grows into a man over the course of the game. The player can dress in whatever they so choose as to also have as many tatoo's or whatever hair style they want. This game has taken a special spot in my heart for most memorable RPG's!

reviewText:
Nostalgia.
I played the original Fable as a kid on the Xbox and in my opinion Fable was easily TOP 3 best RPG's among the original xbox titles. Wether you're a kid, a teenager, or an adult, you've GOT TO BUY THIS GAME NOW!
You'll really enjoy the in-game experience of creating your own story & crafting your Hero or Villain within the land of Albion. Every choice you make shall determine your alignment, thus altering your appearance. As you complete quests and perform good or bad deeds, the people of Albion will begin to recognize you everywhere you go. Will you be feared, or loved?

...and hey, why not stop by at the Pub and gamble over some Table Coin Golf? Buy a round a beers for everyone & fancy your luck with the ladies. Hell, why not marry a fine woman in every town across the land!

reviewText: Alright, well if you actually have been thinking of getting a Fable. I must say, this is the only good one, now shut up about its graphics and somewhat poor combat, the storyline and all that has made up for that, you start out as a poor little boy and later into the game you can be a really Powerful Wizard or a Overpowered Knight, there are many weapons (Not with the greatest names..) but there is a LOT of weapons to choose from, the Armor in this game is outstanding! First you start as a lil' lamb on the hill, then you become an Evil King sent to destroy either whoever gets in your way or just to belch in a traders face! Great game! i would easily give this game a 10/10!!! This game has not only invited me into Chicken-kicking but has also made me find the liking of... Hmm, well playing air Guitar while fighting Towns-guard... Don't mind me im just killing a loop of guards for evil points. Ah yes, Evil and Good. Most of your Killing effects your allignment of the world, you can play a butterfly wizard or be a revolting demon archer, not only do the horns look fantasticly cool, but actually kind of scary, the Halo and butterflys that are above your head when you play good, is quite conforting and sets the Im a Good Guy" to the players face. The villagers make funny remarks to you during your somewhat linear gameplay

reviewText: A very good RPG with a nice story. Leveling up your character is kind of like the system in Elder Scrolls, the more you use some kind of attack the better you get at it and can get new skills. The game puts you in a position to chose how you can do a quest and in the end if you did it in a bad way you will get some bad points or a good way to get good points. You can become good, evil or in between and every choice you make has consequences on the world. Dialogues are very witty. All in all, a very nice, smart game.

All around very good game would definitely reccomend.

reviewText:
I've played Fable in so many ways over so, so many years. I was one of the poor fools waiting years for it to come out, and event hen I was kinda late to the party.

All you really need to know is that this game -should- be awful. It failed the hype more than any other game in the history of ever (except maaaybe Duke Nukem Forever, because that one is awful), the graphics were not what they could have been, the combat shouldn't be fun, the voice acting is painful, the story is simplistic, and a few of the design decisions for models still hurt my brain.

But the game is wonderful. For all that is 'missing', your mind is happy to fill it in, for all that combat should be a boring slog, every player will try a handful of weird rules and challenges, or, just goof off entirely, and get their fun. Collectibles are at once plentiful, and achievable without aid. Marriage is utterly pointless and unfulfilling. . .that's it, marriage is just pointless and unfulfilling. >.> Meta humor >.>

Point is, there is no reason this game should be so awesome, and that's why it stands out as the shining beacon of See here! This is what matters!" - Aesthetics. Every individual piece seems mismatched
recommended: and frankly lacklustre on its own. Put them together and. . .you know the rest. Personally
hoursPlayed: I find this games sits with precious few others on that point of pure aesthetic gold
voteText: and among western-produced RPGs? It almost stands alone.\n\nBacking away from cartoonishness severely damaged the franchise

Hello there! If you're reading this, you're looking for a review on Fable: TLC, and i aim to please you with such.

Fable - The Lost Chapters ( Fable:TLC for short) is the PC-Port of the game Fable 1 with added content & storyline, which also got released on the Xbox slightly after, the game focuses on being an action third player person view game which allows you to roleplay and costumize your character(hero) whether it be through skill, personality or appearance in various different ways.

Throughout the entire game, you'll be given choices of which are categorized by beither either good" or "evil"
recommended: you gain points for each one

reviewText: GOOD GAME. GOOD STORYLINE. LOOKING FOR MORE LIKE THIS
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
played this not-quite-legally the first time around, but it's one of the greatest games I know so I had to buy it eventually.
The story is epic, the music is just wonderful, and the choices you can make show the whole roleplay side of things. Most likely you won't see the plot twists coming, the twists and turns of the story are amazing.
One downside, that isn't really a downside just side you can abuse greatly, is the economics. By realising that everything works in a supply and demand way, and that traders have infinite money, you can easily make over a million gold before even going through darkwood.

All in all, I think the game is wonderful and would gladly recommend it!

reviewText: Big fan of the Fable series, this is without a doubt the best of the bunch. It's so enthralling that I've replayed it at least a million times. It offers so much that it is difficult to put away once you start it. I highly recommend this game to any RPG fans as it is truly a role playing masterpiece.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I played this game a long time ago, and I remember having a lot of fun.

So nostalgically recalling all the good times I had, I recently purchased the original Fable to play, hoping to recreate the experience.

Sadly, I must report that I was severely disappointed. The game is just so outdated, I can't play for five minutes straight without rolling my eyes.

The biggest issue I had was with the combat system. I built a warrior/rogue character because I wanted to enjoy some skill-based combat. However, I found that I was locked onto an enemy, it was difficult to switch between multiple targets with accuracy. This made it hard to block incoming attacks from the flanks or focus on different enemies. So I stopped locking onto enemies, but this made it extremely difficult to use the Assassin Rush skill as it required me to lock on to a target (which is almost random), use the skill, and then stop locking on. Destroys my groove.

Also, the stealth mission at the beginning of the game is terrible.

Needless to say, this was an amazing game for its time. However, I think replaying this game has made me realize and appreciate how much game design has advanced in the years since its release.

So if you remember this being a great game, I suggest that you just hold on to those memories and spend your money on something else. I recommend something more recent.

reviewText: A polished and entertaining ride, jam packed with people to see and things to do. The graphics are nice, the voice acting is superb, and the combat is a lot of fun. Despite the games open ended experience, I still come back to play it every now and than, despite completing several times over since the day it came out on the original Xbox.\n\nFable has aged remarkebly well and deserves the attention of new and old fans of the genra. 84/100
